Abstract:

This paper presents a novel approach to probabilistic parsing by introducing a generative probabilistic model of natural language known as History-based Grammars (HBG). The HBG model incorporates a rich set of linguistic information including lexical, syntactic, semantic, and structural data from parse trees to effectively resolve ambiguities in natural language sentences. Utilizing a Treebank and decision tree building techniques, the HBG model is able to extract relevant aspects from the parse tree to determine the correct parse of a sentence.

The HBG model is tested against the P-CFG, a robust probabilistic parsing model, and demonstrates a significant increase in parsing accuracy from 60% to 75%, which corresponds to a 37% reduction in error rate. This is achieved by using history-based information that includes any already determined elements of the parse tree, such as words and non-terminal categories, to influence parsing decisions.

The paper also discusses the methods for estimating the parameters of the HBG model using decision trees, and how the history-based approach surpasses the context-free grammar model by allowing for richer context in the parsing process. The success of the HBG model suggests that history-based grammars are a promising direction for future research in natural language understanding, and that further improvements could be achieved with larger training corpora.

Abstract:

This paper presents a novel probabilistic parsing model known as History-based Grammars (HBG), which integrates detailed linguistic information such as lexical, syntactic, semantic, and structural elements from the parse tree to enhance the disambiguation process in natural language parsing. The model employs a rich context for parsing by utilizing a Treebank in conjunction with decision tree building to extract relevant aspects of parse trees for accurate sentence parsing. HBG's performance has been compared against an existing robust probabilistic parsing model, Probabilistic Context-Free Grammars (P-CFG), demonstrating a significant improvement in parsing accuracy from 60% to 75%. This improvement corresponds to a 37% reduction in error rate. HBG's superior performance suggests that incorporating extensive contextual information from derivation histories and decision tree technology can greatly enhance the accuracy of probabilistic parsing models. Future work will involve expanding the size of the training corpus and exploring various aspects of derivation history to further improve the accuracy of HBG and similar models.

**Abstract:**

This paper introduces the History-based Grammar (HBG) model, a generative probabilistic model for natural language parsing that leverages a rich array of linguistic information to disambiguate sentence structures. Unlike traditional probabilistic context-free grammars (P-CFG), HBG incorporates lexical, syntactic, semantic, and structural details from parse trees to inform the parsing process. The authors employ a Treebank and decision tree building to identify relevant aspects of parse tree history, which aids in determining the correct parse of a sentence. The HBG model is shown to significantly outperform P-CFG in tests, achieving a 75% parsing accuracy rateâ€”a 37% reduction in error. The paper discusses the motivation behind HBG, its definition, the task domain, and the experimental results, which suggest that HBG presents a more effective approach to parsing than P-CFG. The authors also highlight the potential for further improvements in HBG's accuracy with larger training corpora and richer context models.

Abstract:

This paper introduces a generative probabilistic model for natural language parsing, named History-based Grammar (HBG), which leverages rich linguistic information to resolve ambiguities in sentence parsing. HBG incorporates lexical, syntactic, semantic, and structural information from the parse tree, using decision tree building on a Treebank corpus to identify relevant aspects for correct parsing. This contrasts with traditional approaches that rely on grammar tailoring through linguistic introspection.

In tests against a robust probabilistic parsing model, P-CFG, HBG significantly outperformed, improving parsing accuracy from 60% to 75%, representing a 37% reduction in error. The HBG model integrates insights from previous works into a unified framework, predicting the parse tree of a sentence based on the joint probability of generating the word string and the parse tree, thus utilizing a rich context model.

The paper details the motivation behind HBG, the task domain, the grammar used, the proposed model, and experimental results comparing HBG with the existing P-CFG model. HBG uses decision tree technology to exploit contextual information from the discourse history for probabilistic modeling. The success of HBG suggests that history-based grammars are a promising direction for future research, potentially improving with larger training corpora and varied aspects of derivation history. The paper advocates for a new approach to grammar development, separating the task into grammar coverage and statistical modeling to enhance the selection of correct parses.

  <S sid="140" ssid="140">Resu l ts We compared the performance of HBG to the "broad- coverage" probabilistic ontext-free grammar, P-CFG.</S>
  <S sid="141" ssid="141">The any-consisgen$ rate of the grammar is 90% on test sentences of 7 to 17 words.</S>
  <S sid="142" ssid="142">The Vigerbi rate of P-CFG is 60% on the same test corpus of 760 sentences used in our experiments.</S>
  <S sid="143" ssid="143">On the same test sentences, the HBC model has a Viterbi rate of 75%.</S>
  <S sid="144" ssid="144">This is a reduction of 37% in error rate.</S>
  <S sid="145" ssid="145">Accuracy P-CFG 59.8% HBG 74.6% Error Reduction 36.8% Figure 4: Parsing accuracy: P-CFG vs. HBG In developing HBG, we experimented with similar mod- els of varying complexity.</S>
  <S sid="146" ssid="146">One discovery made during this experimentation is that models which incorporated more context than HBG performed slightly worse than HBG.</S>
  <S sid="147" ssid="147">This suggests that the current raining corpus may not contain enough sentences to estimate richer models.</S>
  <S sid="148" ssid="148">Based on the results of these experiments, it appears likely that significantly increasing the size of the train- ing corpus should result in a corresponding improvement in the accuracy of HBG and richer HBG-like models.</S>
  <S sid="149" ssid="149">To check the value of the above detailed history, we tried the simpler model: 1. p(Ht IH~p, H=p, Rp, Ipc) 2. p(H2 IHx, Hxp, H2p, Rp, Ip~) 3. p(Sy  IH1, Rp, I 0) 4. p(sem ISy., H1, Rp, Ipc) 5. p(R ISyn, Sam, H1, H2) This model corresponds to a P-CFG with NTs that are the crude syntax and semantic ategories annotated with the lexical heads.</S>
  <S sid="150" ssid="150">The Viterbi rate in this case was 66%, a small improvement over the P-CFG model indicating the value of using more context from the derivation tree.</S>
  <S sid="151" ssid="151">Conclusions The success of the HBG model encourages future de- velopment of general history-based grammars as a more promising approach than the usual P-CFG.</S>
  <S sid="152" ssid="152">More ex- perimentation is needed with a larger Treebank than was used in this study and with different aspects of the derivation history.</S>
  <S sid="153" ssid="153">In addition, this paper illustrates a new approach to grammar development where the pars- ing problem is divided (and hopefully conquered) into two subproblems: one of grammar coverage for the gram- marian to address and the other of statistical modeling to increase the probability of picking the correct parse of a sentence.</S>
